summary: This is an FBI NY case summary document detailing the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of minors, initiated in December 2018. It covers victim identification, co-conspirator interviews, digital evidence collection, financial analysis, and key events up to August 2019, including Epstein's suicide and a planned search of his Virgin Islands property.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sexually abusing dozens of minors at his residences in New York, Florida, the Virgin Islands, and New Mexico, by luring them with paid massages that turned sexual.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: As U.S. Attorney in 2007, he met with Epstein's attorneys and offered a non-prosecution agreement, which allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state solicitation charges. Later served as U.S. Secretary of Labor.

persons.name: Nick Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) who was present when Epstein was found unconscious with marks on his neck on July 23, 2019. He is a former police officer charged in a quadruple homicide.

persons.name: Gregory Bledsoe
persons.context: A doctor hired by the Secret Service to provide medical services for Bill Clinton during a 2002 trip to Africa on Epstein's plane. Interviewed by FBI/SDNY and stated he observed no minors or sexual misconduct on the flight.

persons.name: Wexner
persons.context: Represented by attorneys from Debevoise, who advised the FBI/SDNY that Wexner and his wife Abigail were not close with Epstein, had no knowledge of his sexual misconduct, and severed ties in 2007 after discovering Epstein stole money from them.

persons.name: Abigail Wexner
persons.context: Mentioned alongside her husband Wexner in an attorney proffer stating they had no knowledge of Epstein's misconduct and severed ties with him in 2007.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, offered Epstein a non-prosecution agreement in 2007, leading to Epstein's state guilty plea.
Epstein managed finances for Wexner and his wife, from whom he allegedly stole hundreds of thousands of dollars, leading to severed ties in 2007.
Bledsoe was hired for a trip on Epstein's plane in 2002 to provide medical services for Bill Clinton's Secret Service detail.
Tartaglione was Epstein's cellmate at the MCC when Epstein was found unconscious in his cell on July 23, 2019.

events.title: FBI NY Case Initiation
events.description: FBI NY initiated a case after SDNY contacted them regarding several victims sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein in the mid-2000s.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Epstein was arrested in New Jersey upon arrival at Teterboro Airport and transported to New York. A search warrant was executed at his Manhattan residence.

events.title: Epstein Pleads Not Guilty
events.description: Epstein pled not guilty during his initial appearance in federal court.

events.title: Epstein Denied Bail
events.description: Epstein was denied bail during his detention hearing.

events.title: Epstein Found Unconscious in Cell
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his MCC cell with red marks on his neck. He was revived but could not recall what happened. His cellmate was Nick Tartaglione.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: FBI NY was notified that Epstein committed suicide in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in Manhattan.

events.title: Planned Search of Virgin Islands Property
events.description: A search warrant was to be executed at Epstein's Virgin Islands property, led by NY ERT with approximately 60 personnel.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Epstein and his co-conspirators were offered a non-prosecution agreement by then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta, requiring Epstein to plead guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to state solicitation charges and was sentenced to 18 months in jail, serving approximately 13 months with work release.

locations: Little St. James, U.S. Virgin Islands (Epstein's property)
Teterboro Airport, Bergen County, New Jersey
St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands (U.S. Courthouse)
keyFacts: Approximately 60 victims have been identified, with potentially hundreds unidentified; over 20 victims have been interviewed by FBI NY.
Epstein's modus operandi involved inviting minors to his residences for paid massages that turned sexual, paying them $200 and up, and encouraging them to recruit other minors.
Epstein committed suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019.
A 2007 non-prosecution agreement orchestrated by then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state solicitation charges and serve a reduced sentence.
The document references multiple co-conspirators and assistants who helped schedule appointments and recruit victims, with one co-conspirator in London yet to be served.
